;救护车刺耳的叫声，红蓝灯闪烁，宣告着Samira的到来阿尤布和她的三个孙女：14 岁的 Rimas、12 岁的 Talin 和最小的 Layan，只有 10 岁。他们回到了黎巴嫩南部小镇布利达的家，似乎所有居民以及议员和邻近城镇的人们都在主广场附近迎接他们。街道的一侧是穿着黑色罩袍和长袍的妇女，许多人手里拿着三个女孩的 A4 大小的肖像。他们向救护车上扔了大米、粉色和白色的九重葛花瓣。另一边站着身着制服的青少年和来自真主党伊玛目马赫迪童子军的男子，该童子军是黎巴嫩童子军联合会下属的一个青年组织。

;

;四具棺材从救护车上运出，高高地抬过布利达狭窄的街道走向墓地。女孩们的棺材上覆盖着印有童子军徽章的白旗，上面还放着花圈。他们祖母的衣服上披着黑色天鹅绒，上面绣着伊斯兰诗句。一辆装有扬声器的皮卡车铺平了道路。当游行队伍经过一片橄榄园时，一名手持麦克风的年轻人高呼：“以色列去死吧！美国去死吧！”

;

;周日晚上，一架以色列无人机烧毁了他们家的汽车，导致四人死亡。以色列国防军后来告诉《以色列时报》，他们击中了一辆“载有几名恐怖分子的可疑车辆”。里面没有男人。女孩的母亲霍达幸存下来，目前仍在医院接受治疗。他们的父亲马哈茂德在非洲工作。 （黎巴嫩严重的金融危机在 2019 年震惊了整个国家并持续产生影响，迫使许多黎巴嫩公民到国外赚钱。）他回到布利达参加葬礼。

;

;在墓地，马哈茂德哭了当他把头放在女儿的每一个棺材上时。 “我亲爱的，我的生命，你就是我的生命，”马哈茂德一次又一次地说。他自己的父亲就站在他旁边。扩音器里，一名男子正在谈论加沙、抵抗以色列、保卫土地、国际法的双重标准和胜利，而马哈茂德则平静地、伤心地向女儿告别。 “这些是我的孩子，”他对周围的人低声说道。 “你孩子怎么样？看看我的。我的孩子们在天堂。没有人会再问我他们怎么样了。”

;

;我在葬礼上遇到的当地英语老师拉尼娅告诉我，“在这之后我们就什么都不确定了。我认为回应将会很艰难。抵抗组织必须采取行动。”她指的是真主党。

;

;萨米拉和她的孙女在同一天被杀，在黎巴嫩南部其他地方，一架以色列无人机袭击了两辆救护车附近，造成四名护理人员受伤。 （以色列国防军表示，它的目标是一支“恐怖分子小队”。）以色列对平民和紧急车辆的袭击标志着当前冲突的危险的新升级。然而，对于许多黎巴嫩人来说，这感觉就像是似曾相识。 2006 年，七月战争（以色列人称之为第二次黎巴嫩战争）爆发后仅几天，就有 23 名平民（其中许多是儿童）在逃离边境附近的小村庄马尔瓦欣 (Marwahin) 时在以色列的空袭中丧生。其他类似的罢工也随之而来。救护车也成为攻击目标。

;
;
;

;以色列和真主党之间的最新一轮敌对行动于 10 月 8 日开始，即 < a href="https://www.newyorker.com/news/daily-comment/israels-calamity-and-after">;哈马斯在以色列的毁灭性伏击;。联合国划定的黎巴嫩和以色列边界（被称为“蓝线”）自 2006 年战争以来一直相对平静，但现在在不断升级的日常暴力冲突中再次陷入战火。至少有 10 名黎巴嫩平民被杀，其中包括一名路透社记者，还有两名以色列平民。

;

;11 月 3 日，真主党秘书长赛义德·哈桑·纳斯鲁拉 (Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah) 发表了备受期待的讲话，赞扬了他考虑了黎巴嫩前线的成就：转移了本来可以用于入侵加沙的以色列军事资源，使以色列北部的数千名居民流离失所，并灌输了对以色列北部的恐惧。 newyorker.com/news/dispatch/the-simmering-lebanese-front-in-israels-war">;全面的地区战争;，他将这种情况描述为“现实的可能性”。他直接指责美国支持以色列在加沙的进攻，并警告说，任何更广泛的冲突都将成为美国利益的目标。 “八十年代初在黎巴嫩击败你们的人还活着，和他们在一起的还有他们的子孙，”他说。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;美国航空母舰的威胁——最近几周已将两个打击群转移到中东——也没有纳斯鲁拉表示，阿拉伯和西方外交官的请求将影响真主党的算计。只有两个决定因素：以色列在加沙和黎巴嫩的行动。他说：“凭借所有的诚意、透明度、明确性和建设性的模糊性，我们黎巴嫩战线上的所有可能性都是开放的。”他警告说，如果以色列针对黎巴嫩平民，真主党将遵循新规则，“以平民对付平民”。本周末，纳斯鲁拉将再次发表讲话，纪念在战斗中阵亡的真主党战士。

;
;
;

;萨米拉和她的孙辈遇袭数小时后，真主党向什莫纳镇发射火箭弹，以色列北部的一个小镇。 （已经大部分撤离。） 英语老师拉尼娅告诉我，布利达的一些人预计这将是一个转折点。她说，他们离开城镇是为了让真主党战士能够对以色列进行报复，而不会因平民的存在而感到受到阻碍。

;对战争扩大的担忧已经导致超过两万五千人逃离黎巴嫩边境地区，约有一万人在南部城市提尔寻求庇护。上周，提尔市危机管理管理局局长莫尔塔达·姆纳 (Mortada Mhanna) 与几名红十字会志愿者和市政工作人员坐在办公室的一张长桌旁。墙上有两个屏幕，一个显示半岛电视台的滚动新闻，另一个显示流离失所者的统计。他没有太多时间聊天。 “五分钟，可以吗？”他告诉我。他说，大多数流离失所者被安置在以前空置的公寓里或与亲戚住在一起，大约八百人被分散在四所作为避难所的学校里。 “我为一万人准备了六千张床垫，”姆纳说。 “每天，我们都必须为食物和床垫而战。”

;

;他已经捉襟见肘，而且资金不足，而且担心边境局势进一步升级，仅提尔地区就有十万人涌入。 “这比 2006 年更困难，因为援助像点滴一样到达，”他说。据联合国称，在 2006 年战争中，多达一百万人流离失所。如今，黎巴嫩的状况明显更糟，是一个因领导层空缺而陷入瘫​​痪的破产国家。该国已经一年多没有总统了。令人衰弱的金融危机使大约百分之八十的人口陷入贫困。人们都在努力养活自己，更不用说别人了。 “国际非政府组织并没有像我们处于战争中一样来处理这种情况，”姆纳说。 “我坐在提尔，我说我们正处于战争之中。边境地区正在发生战争。这是前线。”

;

;历史在被记录和重述之前，已经被二十五岁的萨拉·法拉杰 (Sara Faraj) 和她六十岁的母亲纳瓦尔 (Nawal) 等女性所生活和重温。 。他们来自南部边境的艾塔阿什沙卜村。 2006 年战争期间，萨拉还是个孩子，她流离失所，住在邻近 Rmaych 村的一所学校里。大约一个月来，她发现自己又回到了教室，这次是在提尔，现在和自己的孩子以及其他几位亲戚在一起。学校的底层住着来自几个边境村庄的其他十几户家庭，而一楼继续接待学生和正常上课。

;

;在 2006 年战争中，她村里的清真寺公开广播了一条信息逃跑。这一次，萨拉和她的家人没有等待。 “我们现在已经习惯了，”她说。 “我们立即决定离开。”他们什么也没带来。她的孩子们穿着捐赠的衣服。姆纳和他的团队已经在努力储存加热器和毯子，以备流离失所者在学校避难所过冬。莎拉六岁的大女儿不明白为什么她不能回家，并且怀念玩玩具的日子。 “他们做得不太好，”萨拉告诉我。 “他们在这里很无聊。我记得关于 2006 年战争的一切，所有的一切，但主要是恐惧，我担心这场战争会对我的孩子们造成什么影响。”

;

;Nawal 一边看着她的孙子们，一边吸着香烟。她的家在2006年的战争中被毁；随后，她用推土机推平了残骸并重建了它。还有更古老的冲突：以色列对黎巴嫩南部大片地区（包括她的村庄）长达二十二年的占领，于 2000 年结束。在此之前，在六七十年代，她记得“巴勒斯坦人会从我们的国家发射火箭”。村庄，以色列人将袭击巴勒斯坦人，”她说。 “这太可怕了。多么美好的回忆啊！我们还想要什么？我们的问题是我们出生在以色列旁边的这个国家。”

;
;
;

;在提尔的黎巴嫩德国大学，该大学有这些家庭也被改造成避难所，来自距离边境约一百米的 Dhayra 村。居民称，炮击已损坏了当地两打以上的房屋。据国际特赦组织报道，10月16日，以色列用含有白磷的炮弹轰炸了该村庄，违反了国际人道主义法。那次袭击后许多人逃离。据说村里只剩下不到十二人。

;

;上周，纳斯拉拉发表演讲的前一天晚上，最后一批坚持抵抗的人之一纳德·阿博·萨里 (Nader Abo Sari) 将他的红色拖车停在德国大学外。他没有留下来的意思；他来城里只是为了出售收获的烟草。他的拖车里塞满了长方形的粗麻布包装，里面塞满了干烟叶。他的妻子带着四个年幼的孩子来到更北的地方与父母住在一起，但阿博·萨里拒绝离开他的村庄，他觉得自己有义务照顾他的几头牛、羊和鸡，并喂养流浪猫和被遗弃的猫。动物。 “这些天总是很紧张，”他站在离拖拉机一段距离的地方说道。 “我醒来时不是听到祈祷声，而是听到炮弹袭击我们地区的声音。” 2006年，阿博·萨里表示，他在西顿市的一座清真寺寻求庇护，该市距离贝鲁特约半小时车程。这一次，他不会离开，除非“以色列人袭击村庄并将我赶出去。”

;

;几天后，我打电话给阿博·萨里，了解达拉的情况。他说，最近有四、五个家庭回到了家。 “人们已经受够了，”他说。 “他们厌倦了流离失所。这是战争，但不是战争。说这是平安，是为了心理上感觉更好——这不是平安。这并不让人放心。如果一个人想回来，并不能保证事情会平静下来或变得更好。而且，如果你想离开家，过上流离失所的生活，那是一种耻辱。”

;

;至于他的处境，他说他已经“适应了”，并开玩笑说导弹袭击打破了单调。的乡村生活。 “这就是行动，”他笑着说道，然后邀请他去达拉共进午餐。 “这会很棒，”他说。 “每年的这个时候，这个村庄都很美丽。” ♦

;鲍里斯·莫卡 (Boris Mocka) 相信，在某一时刻，他发明的领带结比地球上任何人都多 —如此之多，以至于他开始称自己为“领带专家”。大多数打领带的人都熟悉四手结，或许还有温莎结和半温莎结。但还有很多其他的：普拉茨堡、卡文迪什、汉诺威。 1999 年，两位物理学家出版了一本名为“;打领带的 85 种方法;。”然而，他们的统计还远远不够全面。 ;Mocka; 独自创造了更多超过一千五百节。栀子花看起来像一朵花； Wicker 和 Mockatonic 看起来像折纸。谜语者看起来像一个问号，而埃克苏西亚则需要不止一条领带。 “我非常痴迷于原创，”莫卡告诉我。

;

;莫卡不是物理学家，也不是男装设计师，而是我公寓楼的门卫。他的服装发明之路和他的丝绸作品一样曲折。他 1969 年出生于马提尼克岛，在巴黎长大。他的父亲在他两岁时就去世了，他的母亲搬到了纽约，没有他的陪伴。他被一个在空闲时间画画的人收养，并激励莫卡开始绘画。莫卡十岁时，人们告诉他，他的艺术技巧是上帝的恩赐。 “我们更清楚，因为这叫做实践，”他说。

;

;十一岁时，莫卡在纽约与他的生母团聚，她在那里为法国领事馆工作，他最终加入了联合国国际组织学校。他与母亲的关系紧张，他偶尔会逃跑并露宿街头。 （他们不再说话，也无法联系到他的母亲发表评论。）最终，他与雕塑家的一位家庭成员成为了朋友 ;克拉斯·奥尔登堡;，帮助他进入了一流的艺术学校库珀联盟学院。然而，在莫卡入学之前，他被征召入伍并被运送到马提尼克岛。他用头撞了一名教官，并在法属圭亚那的一个流放地度过了一段时间。服役只剩下一个月了，他想退役。他指定的精神科医生告诉他，以精神错乱为借口是唯一的选择，所以他这么做了。

;

;莫卡告诉我，当他回到纽约时，他一度无家可归并有自杀倾向。 “我在朋友家之间来回走动，直到我不再受到欢迎为止，”他说。 “我睡过火车，睡过楼梯。”为了赚点钱，同时也为了向自己证明自己可以打败任何人，他参加了地下裸拳拳击比赛，使用的是他在军队学到的法国跆拳道。 （他说他从未输过。）他在东村教授格斗课程，运送大麻，并担任搬运工。最后，他在第二大道熟食店工作了十年，在那里他遇到了妻子，并从清洁工晋升为经理，这使他能够租用自己的公寓。

;

;莫卡发明了他的第一个领带结2013年，他四十四岁。他的妻子怀孕了，他需要健康保险，所以他找到了一份工会工作，在他的一个朋友工作的公寓楼里担任门卫。第一天上班的前一天晚上，他熬夜学习打温莎结，希望能给人留下好印象。

;

;当莫卡上班时，他的朋友正准备回家。 “我太兴奋了，”莫卡告诉我。 “我一直在说，‘你没看到这有多酷吗？这是完美的温莎。 ”

;
;
;

;他的朋友对此不以为然。 “你知道，你可能想查一下埃尔德雷奇结，”朋友说。 “如果您访问 YouTube，您会找到视频。”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Eldredge 结具有传统结的倒三角形形状。然而，三角形的表面被分成五个重叠的鞘，这使得结看起来几乎像辫子。在学习打领带的过程中，莫卡犯了一些错误。 “但我更喜欢这些错误，而不是结本身，”他说。他开始制作视频来跟踪动作。

;

;很快，莫卡发现了一个专门用于打领带结的在线社区。他发现了像墨洛温系结这样的结，该结以 2003 年电影《黑客帝国：重装上阵》中的一个角色命名；这很不寻常，因为尾巴在刀片前面打结，就好像领带系着一条较小的领带。在 YouTube 上，他开始关注领带传播者，例如加拿大房地产经纪人帕特里克·诺沃特尼 (Patrick Novotny)，他在社交场合会打不常见的领带结以脱颖而出。莫卡最终创作了一千多个自己的视频。他建立或阐明了数十种基本技术：扭转、旋转、盘旋、隧道、蜿蜒、展开。有时他会在半夜醒来，有了一个新的想法，然后哭着叫醒熟睡的妻子，“我明白了！”

;

;在打领带的小世界里，莫卡成为了一个小名人。一位多产的结设计师、南非法庭翻译马布·莱特索阿洛 (Mabu Letsoalo) 称他为天才，对他产生了重大影响。诺沃特尼的领带主题 YouTube 视频观看次数超过两千万，他告诉我，“我认为领带界的每个人都可能会向鲍里斯致敬，因为他发明了最多的结。”然而，这是一件非常难以裁决的事情。莫卡说，他联系了吉尼斯世界纪录，但该组织表示，要创造一项纪录太难了；它的所有记录都必须是可测量的、可打破的、可标准化的和可验证的。关系引发了疑问。领带上的任何结都是领带结吗，还是有规则的？你能简单地通过加捻或打圈将旧结变成新结吗？当你把两个结结合在一起时，它们会变成一个吗？这些不仅仅是美学问题，也是数学问题。

;法国

;纽结理论属于拓扑学的数学领域，它探索数学对象的基本属性。拓扑学家将形状视为橡胶制成的。他们认为立方体和球体是一样的，因为一个可以在没有任何粘合或撕裂的情况下变成另一种。 （数学家有时开玩笑说拓扑学家无法区分甜甜圈和咖啡杯：每个都有一个孔。）根据拓扑学家的说法，结只是一个闭环。最简单的非平凡结是三叶结，它与上手结相同，但绳子的两端相连；在纸上，看起来就像有人画了三叶草。

;
;
;

;在他们的大部分历史中，领带结和结理论是并行发展的。领巾是围巾的一种，在欧洲流行了 1600 年，1828 年出版的《打领巾的艺术》一书包含了 32 门打领巾的课程。现代领带出现于十八世纪五十年代，除了时尚之外几乎没有什么功能。最初的四手结据说得名于一种驾驶马车的方式。十九世纪三十年代，较大的温莎结开始流行。它是以温莎公爵的名字命名的——尽管他实际上戴着四手制的，只是系着大领带。

;

;“拓扑”一词来自德国数学家约翰·李斯汀 (Johann Listing)，他在一本 1847 年的书。 1867 年，结理论又向前迈进了一步，当时物理学家开尔文勋爵受到他的同事彼得·格思里·泰特（Peter Guthrie Tait）吹出的烟圈的启发，提出了原子是以太中打结漩涡的理论。泰特很快就数出了所有有七个交叉点的结。 （有十五个。）虽然他们关于原子的观点被证明是错误的，但纽结的数学成为了它自己的专业。

;结仍然是一个棘手的问题。例如，数学家长期以来认为有一百六十六个结，有十个交叉点，他们使用表格来描述每个结。 1974 年，哈佛大学法学院学生 Ken Perko 浏览了其中一张表格，发现了一些有趣的事情：其中两个结是相同的。 （它们现在被称为 Perko 对。）在更高的维度中，事情会变得更加混乱，或者可能更少。三个维度的结在四个维度上解开；同时，在四个维度上，你可以打结球体。

;

;领带结的艺术和科学终于在九十年代开始融合，当时在剑桥工作的物理学家托马斯·芬克和毛勇了解到领带结是美国人杰瑞·普拉特发明的。一位服装商宣称这是“50 多年来第一个男士新结”。芬克和毛决定对领带结采取泰特对一般结所做的做法：对它们进行分类。他们在《打领带的 85 种方法》中写道：“显然，新领带结的发现是一件罕见的事情。” “我们没有再等半个世纪才下一个结，而是考虑了一种更正式的方法。”

;

;象头神

;将结理论应用于领带，首先想象领带的两端在打结后融合在一起，形成一个闭环。然后考虑一下，领带与传统的结不同，必须缠绕在人的脖子上并垂在他们的胸前。领口和悬垂感这两个特征使领带结成为自己的一个类别。根据标准拓扑，四手和温莎是完全相同的；他们只是三叶草。与此同时，半温莎和普拉特都是无结的——简单的戒指。但是，在实践中，这四个领带结是不同的。

;

;芬克和毛想象了一条领带搭在一个人的肩膀上，领带尾部（即窄端）位于左侧，而刀片（即较宽端）在左侧。 ， 在右侧。他们为刀片的移动方式创建了一种特殊的符号，以及有关顺序的规则。他们将领带结限制为九个动作，最后将刀片向上推向下巴，然后向下穿过一个环。使用他们的符号，在 YouTube 视频中需要几分钟才能解释的内容可以用一小串字符来表示。例如，四手牌是L⊗R⊙L⊗C⊙T：左进、右出、左进、中出、直通。他们认为，基于数学对称性和平衡性，他们的 13 个结在美学上令人愉悦。四把手、温莎、半温莎和普拉特都在其中；据他们所知，其他九个以前从未被描述过。

;
;
;

;Mikael Vejdemo-Johansson，拓扑学家现在在纽约城市大学，2013 年读过芬克和毛的论文。作为一名二十多岁打领结、最终开始打花结领带的数学家，他是他们的理想读者。然而，他发现他们的研究并不令人满意。芬克和毛泽东研究了仅具有平坦表面的结，这排除了更复杂的创造，例如埃尔德雷奇和墨洛温纪。 “芬克和毛基本上只是定义了所有有趣的事情，”Vejdemo-Johansson 告诉我。

;

;Vejdemo-Johansson 知道，你可以用领带做无数的事情。由于大多数领带结都太无聊或奇怪，所以你必须制定规则 - 但规则也不能太严格。他决定与几位合作者进行自己的关系研究。他们认为结最多可以有十三个动作，可以穿过多个环，并且不需要以与芬克和毛的结相同的顺序结束。他们还认为，尾巴而不是刀片可以起带头作用，这是像 Eldredge 一样打出复杂结的唯一方法。

;

;数学家和计算机科学家经常研究形式语言，它们有自己的形式语言有关顺序的符号和规则。 Vejdemo-Johansson 将他的领带结描述为一种独特的语言，具有自己的符号和语法。他和他的同事表明，他们的语法本质上比芬克和毛的语法更复杂，因为有些动作只能与其他动作结合使用：你必须先形成循环，然后才能将领带塞进去。但对于计算工具来说，枚举该语言中的所有“句子”或结并不太复杂。

;

;2015 年，该团队发表了一篇名为“;联系比我们想象的更多;。 ”他们的最终统计数字达到了惊人的 266,682。随附的网站 ;tieknots.how;，随机生成的结和教程。然而，由于研究人员没有应用任何美学规则，他们的许多结都很丑。数学尚未征服艺术。

;胸肌

;有一段时间，莫卡将自己的关系变成了一家小企业。只要花五十美元，你就可以寄给他一条领带，他会打个结然后寄回来。只要一小时两百美元，他就会给你绑一条。今年二月，Mocka 自行出版了一本五百页的书，“;如何打结; ”，其中解释了数十种技巧并给出了十六个签名结的说明；他以两百美元的价格出售精装本。但莫卡的创作期在 2015 年左右达到顶峰。他需要专注于养家糊口，而且他对领带粉丝在没有适当版权的情况下抄袭他的作品感到沮丧。一位设计师在听说莫卡想要创造发明最多绳结的世界纪录后，开始与他竞争，“制造出毫无意义的绳结，”莫卡告诉我。 “他们有点搞乱了比赛。”最后，他几乎将所有 YouTube 视频设为私有。

;

;6 月，我邀请 Mocka 和 Vejdemo-Johansson 到我的公寓，以便他们第一次见面。这位数学家首先到达，穿着蓝色实用短裙、正式背心和衬衫，打着三位一体领带结，这是一种现代经典，其外观分为三个对称的面板。他扎着马尾辫，留着灰白的山羊胡子。

;

;当时，莫卡在我的大楼里当搬运工；由于下班了，他没有穿着平时绣着“鲍里斯”名字的工作衬衫，而是穿着 T 恤和卡其裤。 （最近，他被提升为门卫，并开始打着花哨的领带结去上班。）他剃了光头，留着灰白的胡须，没有打领带。

;

;坐在我的餐桌旁，维德莫-约翰逊翻阅着莫卡的书。他显得很兴奋：“我已经能看到那些符号绝对看不到的东西了。”显然，其中的联系比“比我们想象的更多”所想象的还要多。

;

;“我不是数学家，”莫卡说。 “我其实是来看看我是否有妄想症。”他笑了，然后开始解释他书中的一些技术。

;
;
;

;Mocka的一些动作，Vejdemo-约翰逊说，增加了几何复杂性，但没有使结在拓扑上有所不同。其他人则增加了额外的交叉口。不管怎样，维德莫-约翰逊继续说道，数学还没有捕捉到它们。 Mocka 实际上发明了一种新的方言，其语法甚至比专业数学家使用的语法还要复杂。

;

;“你和我的操作方向完全相反，”Vejdemo-Johansson 告诉 Mocka。 “我的目​​标是选择一个盒子并理解它。你的目标是选择一个盒子并超越它。”

;

;莫卡说，他希望能够教计算机用他的技术创造有趣的新设计。但 Vejdemo-Johansson 认为计算机无法实现这一目标。计算机善于遵守规则；莫卡很擅长打破它们。 “你有一个完整的;世界模型;，”Vejdemo-Johansson说。 “你已经了解了你已经磨练了五十多年的时间，了解你周围的世界是如何存在的，以及你如何与它互动。”

;他引用了莫卡的闪闪发光的结，它可以支撑一个像硬币一样闪亮的物体。人工智能可能不知道原创性和古怪性之间的区别；它可能会通过尝试插入汽车的车轮或打领带的人的手腕来重复闪闪发光的结。即使人类反馈将其推向优雅的结，算法也可能很难找到一个。 Vejdemo-Johansson 说，在所有可能的结的空间中，“我的直觉是，有趣的纽带太稀疏了。”最优雅的结可能是远离丑陋的一步，或者只是解开。

;

;“这本书将被称为‘一百万种打结的方法’，”莫卡说。 “我没有科学证据来证实这一点。”

;

;“这很容易，”Vejdemo-Johansson 回答道。他的论文描述了 25 万节；如果选择添加莫卡的一些动作，这个数字就会远远超过一百万。 “一行证明，”他说。这两个人现在是数学合作者。

;我询问了其他几位数学家他们对 Mocka 结的看法。当宾夕法尼亚州乌尔辛努斯学院的拓扑学家尼古拉斯·斯科维尔 (Nicholas Scoville) 在 Zoom 上加入我时，他所系的领带采用了莫卡的一种技术：褶皱形成了三个小杯子，就好像这个结是用来接住面包屑的。斯科维尔后来看了莫卡的书，思考如果莫卡的各种折叠动作与维德莫-约翰逊的语法结合起来会发生什么。 “我无法想象这会产生多少新的领带结，”他说。

;

;华盛顿与李大学的数学家伊丽莎白·丹尼 (Elizabeth Denne) 告诉我，她喜欢结，因为普通人可以与他们。 “很容易告诉你我在做什么，”她告诉我。 “但是你需要的数学可以非常全面。”可以使用几何、代数、组合学和分析来研究纽结。当 Denne 和两名学生发布 ;关于芬克和毛的八十五节的论文;，在 2021 年，他们证明了关于它们的一些事情 - 例如，它们是素数结。 （这意味着，如果你将它们切成两半，你将留下一个平凡的结和一个重要的结。）

;

;在视频通话中，丹尼从莫卡的书中挑选了一个结。 “鲍里斯的工作就像是一锅鱼，”她告诉我。 “我不认为这个人是巅峰，因为他的事情就像是，;垃圾;。”她特别指着结的一处。 “他在这里打了半个弯。然后他将其贯穿起来。他在旁边做的这件事——那是一个单独的结，就在那里。所以这不是一个优质领带结。”至少，她不这么认为。

;
;
;

;需要更多的数学技巧来描述 Mocka 的艺术。结理论通常将绳子视为一维，但绳子也有宽度，这使得它们更像丝带而不是线。因此，领带中的扭曲可能具有数学意义，就像它对称为莫比乌斯带的著名拓扑物体的意义一样。丹尼专门研究物理结理论，该理论考虑了现实生活中丝带或绳索等物体的宽度或体积，但她告诉我，这样做“真的非常非常困难”。 “这几乎就像你的日常结太难了。”没有人能够设法增加摩擦力。墨洛温王朝将不得不等待进一步的研究。

;

;我想知道领带结的数学是否可以应用于其他任何地方——其他科学领域，或者现实世界。 “我不知道领带结之外还有什么用途，”丹尼说。 “但是，没有人认为折纸有用。”她引用了受折叠纸启发的;NASA;技术，例如在太空中展开的星光阴影。当代物理学家将纽结理论应用于量子力学和粒子穿过时空的蜿蜒路径。在湍流流体和电磁场中观察到了结。化学家想象分子结成结来产生特定的性质。生物物理学家有时会谈论 DNA 的拓扑结构，其双链的行为有点像打结的丝带。拓扑异构酶有助于解开它们。

;

;不过，从另一种意义上来说，数学与领带有一些共同点：这只是我们喜欢做的事情，无论它是否具有功能性。有时，人类追求事物的原因很简单：它们很复杂，或违反直觉，或美丽。对领带结的研究可以像结本身一样异想天开和复杂，这可能就足够了。 “我对此感兴趣，因为我对有趣和奇怪的事情感兴趣，”Vejdemo-Johansson 告诉我。

;两个月之前，我决定自学三位一体结。我打开衣柜，挑选了一条条纹领带，希望它能凸显结的独特设计。然后我站在镜子前，我的笔记本电脑离我几步远，开始模仿在线教程。在我最初的几次尝试中，我失败了。我什至不确定自己是否成功，直到我拉动并整理好结。

;

;有几次，我尝试发明一个结。有很多摆弄和捏造的事情。很难说一个动作从哪里结束，另一个动作从哪里开始。从这个意义上说，领带看起来更像是培乐多而不是乐高积木。然而，稍微收紧或放松一下就能让杂乱的排列突然变得对称。这个过程让我想起了数学家谈论他们的研究的方式。有时，你从一个目的地开始，需要弄清楚到达那里的路；有时，你只是从一个想法开始，结果却出乎意料。你迷失了道路，原路返回，然后再次找到它。当你迈出最后一步时，你手中就握着一些新的东西：一个漂亮、严密的证据。

;

;

;莫卡在他的笔记本电脑上调出一张照片。发生了很多事情，但是，在结的顶部，领带刀片朝后，向上刺穿通常将尾部固定到位的织物环。这个结看起来就像一张精心折叠成环的餐巾。

;

;;去年，内森·菲尔德 (Nathan Fielder) 引发了; ;激烈; ;关于道德和真实性的辩论;与“;《排练》;”——一部 HBO 的“纪录片喜剧”，我觉得既引人入胜又令人震惊——所以感觉他第一次涉足有剧本的电视节目都关注相同的主题。 ;《诅咒》;将于今晚在 Showtime 首映，讲述了一场“慈善”翻屋节目的拍摄过程，已婚的搭档主持人阿舍尔（菲尔德饰）和惠特尼·西格尔（艾玛·斯通饰）取代了苦恼的人。新墨西哥州埃斯帕尼奥拉的房产拥有环保且价格明显更高的房屋。婚姻、拍摄和社区中不可避免地会出现紧张气氛。该剧一半是讽刺，一半是心理恐怖，揭露了电视真人秀令人作呕的诡计和白人自由主义慷慨的局限性。尽管西格尔夫妇坚称他们的项目只会让居民受益，但他们所宣称的价值观很快就被一个非政治性的网络、一个不道德的生产者以及他们对自己如何被看待的焦虑所掩盖。试播几分钟后，有人将薄荷醇吹入癌症患者的眼睛中，模拟感激的泪水。

;
;;
;

;一段陷入困境的浪漫史和制作过程也是大卫·阿吉米 (David Adjmi) 在剧作家地平线 (Playwrights Horizo​​ns) 的出色新剧;“立体声”;的核心。故事发生在十九世纪七十年代的加利福尼亚州，讲述了一支乐队在一张专辑的创作过程中崩溃的故事。戴安娜（莎拉·皮金饰）是一位野心勃勃的歌手，正处于个人事业的风口浪尖。她的长期男友兼主音吉他手彼得（汤姆·佩辛卡饰）不断地为她和其他人发出残酷的音符。 《立体声》和《诅咒》一样，都以自私、善变的角色为基础。但西格尔夫妇的作品从一开始就令人反感，阿吉米却相信所有这些痛苦所产生的艺术。他认为，音乐值得深夜、痴迷地重拍、以及一路上破裂的关系。在《诅咒》的愤世嫉俗之后，主角们一心掩盖自己的真实本性，看到乐队成员为真实的东西而奋斗，令人感动。

;巴勃罗·毕加索逝世五十周年激发了许多大型或深入的展览的灵感。佩斯画廊为庆祝活动做出了杰出的贡献，;“毕加索：14本素描本”;很长，研究了 1900 年至 1959 年间大师的手的演变。这是一个一站式商店，可以买到甚至非爱好者们可以滔滔不绝地讲述（乐器、情妇、锯齿状裸体、眼神邪恶的公牛），当然，还有一些上世纪最好的绘画。在 1924 年完成的宏伟的《女人头像》（如图）中，摇摆不定、任性的印度墨水线条融合成某种坚硬且不可避免的东西——如果毕加索崇拜和毕加索仇恨的对立崇拜让你感到厌烦，那就寻找像这样的图像晒太阳。—;;Jackson Arn;（佩斯；截至 12 月 22 日。）;;

;歌剧
;

;丹尼尔·卡坦 (Daniel Catán) 的;《佛罗伦萨与亚马逊》;是一部无比可爱的歌剧，毫不掩饰地拥抱了后浪漫主义音乐语言大气的木管乐器、颤动的弦乐和闪亮的高音。有些人可能会称其为 1996 年作品的倒退，但它对普契尼的借鉴，很适合讲述 1900 世纪初一位渴望的女主角的故事。当角色们乘坐穿越亚马逊河的河船前往巴西歌剧院时，令人陶醉的乐器音色组合表达了他们的愿望。 For the Met première, Ailyn Pérez, a soprano with an especially warm voice, stars as the titular diva, in a production directed by Mary Zimmerman and conducted by Yannick Nézet-Séguin.—;;Oussama Zahr; (Metropolitan Opera House; select dates Nov. 16-Dec. 14.);

;When ;Bob Dylan; gave his Nobel lecture, after being awarded the 2016 prize for literature, he implored people to take in his lyrics as they were intended: by listening, on record or in concert, not by reading. He quoted Homer, and he pointed to his songs as vehicles for storytelling. “I've searched the world over for the Holy Grail / I sing songs of love—I sing songs of betrayal,” he croaks on “False Prophet,” a single he performs on his “Rough and Rowdy Ways” tour, which comes to New York City this month. His album of the same name, from 2020, is full of glorious Americana, with scenes—from Key West to the Rubicon, the grassy knoll to the city of God—etched by his seasoned delivery. As he puts it, he sings songs of experience, which bear in them not only stories from his travels but the hallowed history of every time he's performed.—;;Sheldon Pearce; (Kings Theatre, Nov. 14-15; Beacon Theatre, Nov. 16.);

;Dance
;
;;
;

;In Rudyard Kipling's “The Jungle Book,” a young boy raised by a family of wolves must choose between life in the animal kingdom and a return to the human world. The British dancer-choreographer Akram Khan posits a different question in his ;“Jungle Book reimagined”:; Is there even a place for humans on a planet they have damaged to the point of near-collapse? Through a mix of audio, animation, and dance, Khan has created a fable about the moral and physical costs of environmental destruction. The protagonist, Mowgli, a girl who has lost her parents to rising seas, is both protected and challenged by the animals who save her, whose thoughts are heard in voice-over.—;;Marina Harss; (Rose Theatre; Nov. 16-18.);

;
;
;Art
;

;In recent years, the Brooklyn Museum has organized shows around non-fine-artist superstars of varying quality and relevance. ;“Spike Lee: Creative Sources”; comprises some four hundred and fifty objects from the director's collection, including the original draft of the screenplay for his first masterpiece, “Do the Right Thing”; a Richard Avedon photograph of Malcolm X; a letter from Barack Obama; and one of Prince's guitars. Indulgent? Sure, but a messy, risky too-muchness has always been one of Lee's strengths, and it seems appropriate here—you come away overloaded but still eager to rewatch the films. As long as the museum is in the habit of giving the reins to celebrities, it might as well give them to Brooklyn's best.—;Jackson Arn (Brooklyn Museum; through Feb. 4.);

;In ;“May December,”; Todd Haynes dramatizes the complex connection between an actress, Elizabeth (Natalie Portman), and a woman, Gracie (Julianne Moore), whom she's planning to portray in a movie. Gracie and her husband, Joe (Charles Melton), are pariahs in their home town of Savannah. Their relationship began when he was just out of seventh grade and she was in her thirties; she was imprisoned, and after her release they married. Now, twenty years later, they have three nearly grown children, and they're desperate for empathetic understanding. Enter Elizabeth, who insinuates herself into the family, gains information—and possibly disinformation—about the couple's troubled life, and exhibits artistic intentions as dubious as her ethical judgment. Haynes deftly sketches a tangle of manipulations and power plays and, along the way, offers a useful reminder: when Hollywood comes for your life story, run.—;;Richard Brody; (Opening Nov. 17 in theatres and streaming on Netflix starting Dec. 1.);

;Off Broadway
;

;Jerome Weidman and the composer Harold Rome's garment-district musical, from 1962—thoughtfully reshaped by Weidman's librettist son, John, and directed by Trip Cullman—feels like being walloped by a roll of velvet. I mean that admiringly: when slippery Harry Bogen (Santino Fontana) takes advantage of his doting mama (Judy Kuhn), his adoring sweetheart (Rebecca Naomi Jones), and his trusting business partner (Adam Chanler-Berat) to get ahead, it ;should; feel like a slug in the gut. ;“I Can Get It For You Wholesale”; is not just a rogue's tale; it's also a labor-movement cri de coeur. Julia Lester, playing Harry's secretary, belts “Miss Marmelstein,” the song that first made Barbra Streisand famous, but it's Lester's glass-shattering “What Are They Doing to Us Now?” that will stamp the price of unregulated, unrepentant capitalism right onto your quaking spirit.—;;Helen Shaw; (Classic Stage Company; through Dec. 17.);

;Pick Three

;;;

;;The staff writer ;Vinson Cunningham; shares current obsessions.;

;;

;;1.; ;Best cinematic interior design:; The more I think about Sofia Coppola's new film, ;“Priscilla,”; about the gilded cage inhabited by Priscilla Presley in her world-famous marriage to Elvis, the more I am enthralled and—reluctantly—seduced by its attention to sumptuous surfaces. Elvis's heavily brocaded bedroom, and the over-the-top beauty of the Presley home in Memphis, Tennessee, is a harrowing metaphor for the claustrophobic effects of patriarchy and the subtle encroachments of abuse.

;
;
;

;;2.; ;Best world-spanning exhibition:; The MacArthur “genius”-grant recipient ;An-My Lê; is one of my favorite artists in any medium. (She is also, I should admit, a friend.) Her photographs inspire deep contemplation at the crossroads of fiction and reënactment, politics and fantasy, the displacements of war and the feelings of home. Her truly epic career retrospective at ;MOMA;—curated by Roxana Marcoci and Caitlin Ryan—spans, with rare rigor and rarer beauty, post-Trump America, postwar Vietnam, the Civil War, and the civic disruptions that follow the making of a nation.

;
;;
;

;;3.; ;Best album bridging today's music to nineties R. & B.:; I have been hopelessly obsessed with ;“The Love Album: Off the Grid,”; the new record by the mega-producer Diddy (formerly known as Puff Daddy), since its September release. The East Coast R. & B. that I grew up with—by such artists as Carl Thomas, Faith Evans, and Mary J. Blige—was shepherded into being, in large part, by Diddy. Now he's made a swoon-inducing, lovesick album that looks back at those sources, infusing them with new voices and fresh sounds.

;Donald Trump often takes the breath away with his defiance of the basic norms of American public life. (See: ;January 6th;.) But sometimes it's the smaller encroachments on decency that serve as a reminder of how far outside the bounds he operates. “Can you control your client?” Judge Arthur Engoron demanded of Trump's lawyer, during the former President's ;testimony on Monday; in Manhattan, where he stands ;accused; of running a fraudulent business in the state of New York. “This is not a political rally. This is a courtroom.” Later, after yet another Trump soliloquy in response to a yes-or-no question, Engoron repeated his entreaty. “I beseech you,” the judge said, “to control him if you can.”

;

;Of course, seven years and five months into Trump's political career, we know by now that there is no controlling Trump. And yet, exactly a year before Election Day, that rogue defendant in the dock is not only the presumptive Republican nominee but ;running in a dead heat; with Joe Biden nationally and, if the shock poll that came out ;in the ;Times;; a day before Trump's testimony is to be believed, ahead of him in five of six must-win battleground states. Trump's lawyer Christopher Kise even bragged about this in Engoron's courtroom, citing the poll as he referred to his client as “the future President of the United States.” The poll's release quickly sent Democratic Washington into a vaporous state of preëmptive blame-gaming about the status of the race: ;It's Biden's age;. ;It's his campaign;. ;It's the media's fault;. ;It's all of the above.; One anonymous sniper told NBC News that the campaign needed a “;defibrillator;.” The former Obama adviser David Axelrod even kinda, sorta, maybe ;suggested; that Biden should consider stepping aside as the Party's 2024 standard-bearer. The White House sought to downplay the fuss as the inevitable outcry from the Party's large class of professional “bed wetters.” Perhaps, one Democratic strategist insisted, albeit anonymously, to ;the Washington ;Post;;, some bed-wetting was in order: “We should be terrified about what might happen.”

;

;The panicky news cycle was interrupted when Tuesday's off-year election results came in: a ;big win; for abortion rights in the increasingly red state of Ohio; a victory for the incumbent Democratic governor, Andy Beshear, in the solidly red state of Kentucky; a Democratic state House pickup in Virginia that looked to spoil the national aspirations of its Republican governor, Glenn Youngkin. Inevitably, team Biden claimed vindication. “Across the country tonight, democracy won and MAGA lost,” the President posted on social media. “Voters vote. Polls don't.”

;

;Days later, though, I'm still struggling to understand the chill-out, everything's-going-according-to-the-plan spin. I know that the spinners have a job to do and that some amount of self-soothing is required in these stressful times. But still, whichever individual poll you choose to believe or not, the data point overwhelmingly to Biden sitting at near-historic lows in popularity and being essentially tied with Trump, a man who is running on an explicit platform of revenge, retribution, and Constitution-termination. As for the predictive power of off-year elections, it's best to remember that the big victory in Virginia amounted to Democrats narrowly holding onto the state Senate—they actually lost a seat—and gaining the state House with a net pickup of three seats, in a state that Biden won against Trump in 2020 by more than ten points. If Democrats had received nineteen hundred fewer votes in a single Virginia Senate district and eight hundred fewer in a single Virginia House district, they wouldn't have won full control of either chamber. That's hardly the reassurance that the Party craves looking ahead to 2024.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Besides, Biden is up against not just electoral math but human psychology. There were plenty of reasonable theories of how and why Trump's appeal would fade once he left the White House and the full folly of his unprecedented effort to block the 2020 election results was revealed. But those theories have not panned out. Instead, Trump has, after four criminal indictments and multiple civil proceedings, such as the trial in New York, opened up such a wide lead against his GOP opponents that watching ;Wednesday night's debate; among the also-rans seemed like an incredible waste of time for any but the most masochistic of Republican viewers. I watched; it was eminently skippable. The short version is that Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina who served as Trump's Ambassador to the United Nations, continued to embarrass her rivals with sharp retorts, offering voters an almost anachronistic attachment to the hawkish foreign policy of the pre-Trump GOP and a reluctance to fully disavow the ex-President she is ostensibly running against. It said everything about this Republican field that, when invited to condemn Trump in the debate's opening question, four of the five candidates onstage offered varying critiques of his electability and conservative record without getting to the heart of the matter. Ron DeSantis complained about Trump not building his wall. Tim Scott lamented his lack of appeal to independents. Haley said Trump wasn't the right President for our political moment. And then there was Vivek Ramaswamy, who demanded that the moderator apologize for even asking such a question.

;
;
;

;More revealing—and far more relevant, given where the race stands—was Trump's own rally that evening, in Hialeah, Florida, which took place as his latest act of counterprogramming during the Republican debate. While talking for well more than an hour, he fulminated about 2024 in nearly apocalyptic terms (“our final battle”) and added a gruesome note that I hadn't heard before about the “liars and leeches” who have been “sucking the life and blood” out of the country. He portrayed himself—and his followers—as victims of a “police state.” (Consistency is never a hallmark of Trump's attacks; he also called Biden's government a feckless “banana republic.”) And he offered plenty of additional fodder to those who think that he, not Biden, has aged out of the Presidency, like when he praised Kim Jong Un, North Korea's dictatorial leader, and mixed up the population size of North Korea with that of China.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;
;

;
;
;
;

;On Thursday, in an ;interview with Univision;, Trump again made explicit what is often implicit in his vengeance-fuelled campaign: his willingness to use the justice system to go after his opponents if he is returned to the White House. Any other prospective President would have denied with all possible force a recent ;Washington ;Post; report; that Trump has already demanded that his aides make plans to target some former advisers who have become public critics, including his former chief of staff John Kelly, former Attorney General Bill Barr, and former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Mark Milley. Instead, Trump all but confirmed the story when he told the Spanish-language network that he would use the courts against his political rivals. “If I happen to be President and I see somebody who's doing well and beating me very badly, I say, 'Go down and indict them,' ” Trump told Univision. “They'd be out of business. They'd be out of the election.”

;

;There should be no surprise in this, of course. When Trump ran in 2016, he promised to jail his opponent, Hillary Clinton, and laughed and cheered and egged on his crowds when they chanted, “Lock her up! Lock her up!”

;

;In an appearance this week on “The View,” Clinton compared Trump to Adolf Hitler, who was, she noted, “duly elected” before he dismantled Germany's democracy and turned himself into a dictator. Her main point—and it bears endless repetition between now and whatever awaits us next November—is that Trump has clearly spelled out exactly how he plans to go after core tenets of American democracy. There is no mystery here. “Trump is telling us what he intends to do,” Clinton said. “Take him at his word. The man means to throw people in jail who disagree with him, shut down legitimate press outlets, do what he can to literally undermine the rule of law and our country's values.”

;

;It's worth noting that Clinton made those comments ;before; Trump's incendiary interview. He's said it all before; he'll say it all again. The question, with one year left on the clock, is: Who's listening? ♦

;周二，最初结果不确定的草根倡议变成了自;最高法院的多布斯判决;，2022 年 6 月，;推翻;罗伊诉韦德案所保障的权利。在一个长期由共和党人主导的州，超过两百万人支持了一项宪法修正案，声称“每个人都有权做出和执行自己的生育决定”。该修正案与罗伊法案一样，允许州政府仅在胎儿存活后才限制堕胎，除非医生认为有必要保护母亲的生命或健康，该修正案通过了超过 13 个百分点。公平项目（Fairness Project）的执行董事凯利·霍尔（Kelly Hall）在红州和紫州推动进步投票措施，她告诉我，“俄亥俄州的胜利确实告诉我们堕胎权运动中的所有人，这几乎在任何地方都是可能的。”

;

;俄亥俄州是今年唯一一个选民对堕胎权进行赞成或反对投票的州，但该州和其他地方的结果提供了新的证据，表明该问题可能会在 2024 年对民主党有利。在弗吉尼亚州，痛斥;格伦·扬金<的反堕胎政策的民主党人<共和党州长保留了州参议院的领导权，并赢得了众议院的控制权。在肯塔基州，民主党州长安迪·贝希尔（Andy Beshear）击败共和党总检察长;丹尼尔·卡梅伦;赢得连任，他支持该州;近乎全面禁令; 关于堕胎。在宾夕法尼亚州，民主党增加了在州最高法院的多数席位，;选举丹·麦卡弗里;，他将堕胎作为其十年任期竞选活动的核心部分。

;

;结果还表明，一些共和党人试图缓和自己的立场，但支持堕胎的选民并未被说服。杨金经常被认为是潜在的总统候选人，他曾说过“生命从受孕开始”，并且他将签署任何法案“;幸福快乐地保护生命;。”但是，在弗吉尼亚州（最后一个广泛堕胎受到保护的南方州）的竞选期间，Youngkin 的政治行动委员会花费了 140 万美元来分发 ;视频广告;宣称支持“合理的十五周限制”，但强奸、乱伦、和母亲的生命，但不适用于胎儿存在致命异常的情况。

;

;在俄亥俄州，堕胎权的支持者认为，该修正案有利于患者而不是政客，并且不仅保护堕胎方面的决定还包括避孕、生育治疗、流产护理和“继续怀孕”等基本卫生规定。他们强调，没有任何已知的医学理由可以限制堕胎，并将选择堕胎视为个人自由问题。周三，俄亥俄州生殖权利联盟联合主席劳伦·布劳维尔特 (Lauren Blauvelt) 表示，选民们“重新获得了在不受政府干预的情况下做出最个人决定的自由。”

;

;俄亥俄州 ;筹集资金和支出<他们向对手投入了数百万美元，并建立了一个跨越党派和地域的联盟，并得到工会、牧师和积极进取的妇女团体的支持。卡马拉·哈里斯，;格雷琴·惠特默;，约翰·传奇 (John Legend) 出面支持这项名为第一期的投票措施。“他们告诉我们，我们是少数派，”邻国密歇根州的民主党州长惠特默在一次虚拟集会上表示，该州于 2022 年批准了一项类似的修正案。 “我们不是。我们是多数。”

;
;
;

;在过去十五个月里，选民在投票问题上保护堕胎权;连续六次;，在堪萨斯州、蒙大拿州、佛蒙特州、加利福尼亚州、密歇根州和肯塔基州。俄亥俄州在等待州最高法院对为期六周的禁令进行审查之前，堕胎仍然合法。为了赢得俄亥俄州的胜利，堕胎权支持者必须克服决心打破堕胎连胜纪录的共和党人的伎俩。

;去年春天，支持堕胎的团体开始收集签名国务卿弗兰克·拉罗斯 (Frank LaRose) 成功推动了 8 月份的公投，将宪法修正案通过的门槛提高到简单多数的 60%，而这一直是俄亥俄州的标准 ;自 1912 年;。就在几个月前，他帮助说服共和党主导的立法机构废除了八月份的特别选举，该选举历来投票率很低，;称它们;“对我们州的公民健康来说是坏消息。”起初，他;坚称;改变规则是只是一个“好政府”的问题。但是，他在向塞尼卡县的支持者发表讲话时表示，这一策略“百分百是为了将激进的堕胎修正案排除在我们的宪法之外”。选民;拒绝了这一举措;提高了十四个百分点。 （如果通过了，设定了百分之六十的门槛，周二的宪法修正案就会失败。）

;相反，董事会以 3 比 2 的投票结果撰写了一份长度大致相同的“摘要”。委员会主席是拉罗斯，他说他对文本进行了“广泛的工作”，其中包括将“胎儿”替换为“未出生的孩子”，并以最不利于堕胎权努力的方式制定修正案。摘要没有明确指出该修正案的具体语言，即国家可以禁止在胎儿存活后堕胎（生命和健康除外），而是声称该修正案“始终允许未出生的孩子在怀孕的任何阶段进行堕胎，无论其情况如何”。生存能力”，如果主治医生认为有必要的话。俄亥俄州生殖权利联合会称这些变化是“他们自己选出的官员赤裸裸地试图误导。”

;

;作为回应，红葡萄酒和蓝组织的领导人做出了回应，该组织动员郊区妇女为进步主义组织工作原因，召开了一次紧急培训会议，以帮助志愿者向选民传达拟议修正案的实际内容。 “只是将全文呈现在尽可能多的人面前，”俄亥俄州团队的项目总监 Jen Perez 说。例如，反对者认为，如果未成年子女怀孕，该修正案将消除父母的权利，因为文本规定“每个人”都有权选择堕胎。然而，;法律专家的共识;是：未成年人的权利可以受到限制。该联盟认为，该修正案实际上加强了父母的权利，他们可以选择帮助孩子选择如何处理怀孕。根据这项为期六周的法律，即使是遭受性侵犯后需要堕胎的孩子也必须离开该州才能堕胎。这种情况发生在去年，当时俄亥俄州一名十岁的强奸受害者被要求前往印第安纳州接受治疗，这起案件引起了全国关注。

;

;在这样的故事中，民意调查显示了一致的支持在堕胎问题上，俄亥俄州共和党州长迈克·德温 (Mike DeWine) 在 2019 年签署了这项为期六周的法律，他在周二投票前的几周内，试图像杨金一样，对反堕胎运动表现出更加温和的态度。他说宪法修正案是一个“激进的提议”，并且在广为人知的三十秒广告中，他和他的妻子弗兰将修正案反对者视为合理的一方。 “无论我们走到哪里，”州长说，“人们都告诉我们他们对第一个问题感到困惑。”弗兰·德温接着说，该修正案将允许“怀孕期间的任何时间”堕胎。 （广告 ;没有通过事实核查人员的审查;。）绝大多数选民有不同的看法，这向堕胎权倡导者发出了一个信号，他们可能会在明年的投票中提出类似的倡议在密苏里州、佛罗里达州和亚利桑那州等州。

;

;在俄亥俄州，共和党领导人表示，周二的结果并不是他们努力的终点。马特·霍夫曼，参议院议长，;预测;“投票活动的旋转门废除或取代第一期。”投票前，我采访了俄亥俄州生命权组织主席迈克·戈尼达基斯 (Mike Gonidakis)。 ;他为多布斯判决的那天欢呼;，当时一位联邦法官在俄亥俄州 ;允许该州的“心跳”法律生效。当我上周与戈尼达基斯交谈时，他并不是在谈论他更喜欢的全面禁令，而是在寻找他所谓的“共同点”。他说，堕胎反对者有责任找到一个成功的方案。 “我们必须回到投票，”他说，“带着一些能通过的东西。” ♦

;十月下旬的一个星期二早上，Sheila Youngblood 开着她的路虎揽胜，驶过田野前往德克萨斯州朗德托普的马尔堡农场放牧马匹。清晨的细雨刚刚停歇，路边开满了黄色的野花。很快，交通变得缓慢起来，野花被装满了令人眼花缭乱的商品的帐篷所取代。一年中的大部分时间里，圆顶的官方人口为 87 人，但在 10 月和 3 月，估计有数十万游客来到这里参观庞大的古董市场，这是世界上最大的古董市场之一。

;

; 自 1968 年两位休斯顿社交名流主办该镇首次拍卖会以来，购物者就被吸引到了圆顶。 90 年代初，Youngblood 第一次与她的祖母一起参观了博览会。 “它很小，只有一些建筑物和田地，”她说。 “但就是有这种寻宝精神。” （Youngblood 回忆道，她的祖母买了很多台灯、地毯和各种小摆设，以至于她不得不用钱包带将林肯大陆车的车门系紧。）

;

;全国各地的其他古董市场关闭后，网上购物的转移造成了损失，但圆顶的集市却变得更大。尽管圆顶镇仍然享有跳蚤市场小镇的美誉，但它正在转变为高档购物圣地。这会让参观感觉有点超现实：这是一个坚持其古朴的地方，尽管它已经迅速发展壮大。随着车流缓缓前行，杨布拉德指出了一年前还不存在的建筑物。 “这是新的，”她说，凝视着窗外一座由巧妙生锈的瓦楞铁皮制成的谷仓状结构，这是一座新购物中心的一部分。 “我认为这家伙正在添加九座建筑物。”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;

;Youngblood 的声音沙哑且喜欢夸张的外观；我见到她的那天晚上，她正在举办一场一百人的晚宴，她穿着黄色长袍，戴着两英尺高的花卉头饰，戴着一串项链，戴着一个冰球大小的绿松石戒指。 “她是 Round Top 的祖母，”时装设计师 Lela Rose 告诉我，然后很快纠正了自己。 “不过，不是年龄！她是。 。 。圆顶的贵妇人。”镇上的购物可能令人难以抗拒——没有一个中央市场，而是有数十个不同的场所，例如马尔堡农场，每个场所都有自己的时间表和自己的供应商集合。年轻的布拉德是德克萨斯人，他已经成为一种非官方的圆顶大使，引导游客度过混乱。她曾与一些不愿透露姓名的名人（据传闻，其中包括格温·史蒂芬妮（Gwen Stefani）和设计师凯莉·韦斯特勒（Kelly Wearstler））一起购物，也曾与名气不大但同样富有的人一起购物。 Youngblood 告诉我：“大多数人都拥有第二套房子、第三套房子，如果您要购买多套房子，这里就是您的最佳选择。”

;

;我们在 9 点正式开业之前到达了 Marburger。 ;AM; 一群群妇女聚集在帐篷周围，想要一睹里面的商品，充满期待的能量。 Youngblood 当天有一个购物日程：她需要为一家名为 Grandma's Clam 的小酒吧提供家具，她计划在奥斯汀开设这家酒吧。 “这会有点不修边幅，但又很精致，非常奶奶式，就像棕榈滩的房地产拍卖一样，”她说。 Youngblood 的朋友大卫·门多萨 (David Mendoza) 加入了她的行列，大卫·门多萨是奥斯汀的一位企业家和酒吧老板，正如他试图向我解释的那样，“也为品牌设计品牌”。他正在购买几个“酒吧概念”，其中一个是他自己的，其他的是客户朋友的。 “一种是马尔蒙城堡的西班牙十九世纪三十年代马海毛沙发枕头流苏的氛围。另一个是硬门考究的夜总会，非常黑的玻璃，白色的兰花。基本上，我希望它看起来像七十年代的 YSL Opium 广告，”他说。他计划今年晚些时候在奥斯汀开设第三家酒吧，灵感来自古罗马，就在帝国灭亡之前：“每个人都在谈论奥斯汀如何成为发展最快的城市，但这一切都可能瞬间适得其反。我想摆脱这种紧张。就像，尽可能获取它。”

;九点钟，购物者涌入帐篷。门多萨和杨布拉德走得很快，浏览着商品，偶尔停下来向熟人打招呼。 （“上次我买了那辆;美妙;雪橇时，我们去哪儿了？”一位穿着流苏夹克的女士问杨布拉德。）门多萨停下来，注视着一对用木头雕刻的胖脸小天使。 “这就是一种氛围，”他赞赏地说。 “我非常喜欢这些，”Youngblood 说。他们对摆放着白色珠皮呢软垫的柚木家具的展位印象不那么深刻。 “我;已经;睡着了，”门多萨说。 “这就是为什么我不担心提前到达这里，”杨布拉德说。 “没有人想要我想要的东西。”一位经销商熟人向她招手。 “你一定要看看这个，这就是你，”他热情地说。所讨论的物体是一条十二英尺长的鳄鱼标本，戴着马鞍和缰绳，长嘴张开，露出邪恶的笑容。 “什么？这太不可思议了，”杨布拉德说。她似乎短暂地受到了诱惑。 “但是我该怎么办呢？” she asked.她决定不买鳄鱼，但很快又买了其他东西：一个手杖和铅笔芦苇柜、一面大点画玻璃威尼斯镜子（“我喜欢它的破碎感”）、一只火烈鸟标本和一套 VIP 礼盒。 - 主题鸡尾酒杯。大约四十五分钟的时间，她花了不到一万美元。

;By 10:30 ;AM;, some shoppers were sipping glasses of rosé. Many were wearing the unofficial Round Top uniform: wide-brimmed hat, flowy floral dress, and boots. “It was quilted jackets last season. I was counting the quilted jackets,” one designer told me. “Now it's those metallic boots. And cowboy hats with stuff stuck in them,” her friend said. (The metallic boots in question, which were everywhere, are designed by Miron Crosby and cost twelve hundred dollars.)

;

;At lunch, Youngblood sat down with Arvin Olano, a fresh-faced Los Angeles content creator with manicured nails and blocky tortoiseshell glasses. Olano started his design-focussed YouTube channel during the pandemic, posting videos with titles like “10 Luxurious IKEA Products Stylist Approved” and “Best & Worst New Target Spring 2022 Decor & Furniture.” “Then I discovered vintage,” he said. For the fair, he was trying out a new technique: custom-made “Sold” stickers printed with his name—that way, shoppers who came after him would see what he'd bought.

;

;The crowds at Round Top were a testament to the market in vintage goods, which surged during the pandemic. “The consumption was just unreal,” Mark Dooley, a longtime Round Top dealer, told me. “You could sell literally anything.” I heard various explanations for this phenomenon: supply-chain issues made buying new items unreliable; travel restrictions meant that wealthy Texans were doing more of their shopping closer to home; after too much time spent glued to screens, people were hungry for objects with a patina and a history. A dealer and designer named Amelia Tarbet sources most of her merchandise in Europe. “It's getting so hard to find decent stuff,” she told me. “What I'm paying for things now is what I would have retailed them for twenty-four months ago. The influencers are hitting vintage hard-core, and pieces can get so trendy so quickly. Round Top has become this gold rush—sometimes it feels like the stock market.”

;
;
;

;But the fair's popularity as a see-and-be-seen destination doesn't always translate to increased sales. “This show is just a pressure cooker,” a Midwestern dealer, who asked me not to use his name, said. The tents were full of tipsy would-be shoppers taking selfies, but the buying wasn't as brisk as he'd hoped. “I'm trying not to panic,” he said. “People don't want to buy from a sad guy. They want to buy from someone who's, like, 'Oh, this is just my hobby.' But this is how I feed my kids.”

;When I told people I was going to meet the mayor of Round Top, they seemed to expect I was in for a charmingly small-town experience. (“Is the mayor a dog?” a friend asked.) In fact, the mayor is a forty-three-year-old property developer from Houston named Mark Massey, who has played a pivotal role in the development—or overdevelopment—of the town. Houston and Austin are among the country's ;fastest-growing cities;; Round Top, an agricultural community situated halfway between the two—about a ninety-minute drive from either—is in the midst of a building boom. Land that sold for ten thousand dollars an acre eight years ago now goes for ten times as much. Across town, hayfields have been replaced by ranchette developments, and the town is full of new construction that tries, with varying levels of success, to look old.

;

;I met Massey at the Compound, former pastureland that he had converted into a “multi-acre master-planned event-and-entertainment venue.” The Compound's central building is a white barn with affirmations painted on its eaves: “Dance Proud”; “Be Kind”; “Say Howdy”; “Dream Big”; “Hug Puppies.” We sat in a gazebo bar that was serving a steady stream of pre-noon drinkers. Massey grew up in Houston; during the summers, he'd visit his grandparents' farm in Round Top for a taste of country life. “You know, fishing, four-wheelers, all that fun stuff,” he said. Massey was working for a developer in Beverly Hills when, in 2010, his mother proposed a family project: they would buy up some old buildings around a historic square in town, restore them, and rent them out to small independent merchants. “That leased out, like, overnight, it seemed,” he said. The town, he realized, had potential. Round Top had what people wanted: “that Hamptons-Aspen-Santa Fe-Marfa kind of feel, you know, that elevated small town,” he said.

;
;
;

;Since then, Massey has gone on to develop several more town squares in Round Top, including the Compound. (The others are named for the area's early German mercantile families: Henkel Square, Minden Square, Fricke Square, Rummel Square.) To assemble them, Massey scoured the countryside for visually pleasing old buildings—“just a quaint cottage look with some character”—to relocate and repurpose. “They put these giant steel beams underneath and lift the house up on a truck,” he said. “Sometimes, depending on the size, they'll cut the house into pieces. So it's literally, like, big sections of house moving down this two-lane highway. They have to raise the power lines. It's crazy. People will pull off the road to take pictures.” Visitors occasionally assume that the developments have been around since the town's founding.

;

;In 2020, Massey was elected Round Top's mayor, winning fifty-four votes to his opponent's thirty-six. His affection for historic preservation has helped insure that, despite the rapid pace of development, Round Top maintains its carefully cultivated image. More than anywhere else I've been, it feels like a small town in a Lifetime movie, where neighbors wave hello and there's not a vape shop, CrossFit studio, or Dollar General to be seen. “People want that life style—going out West, having property, having critters, living off the land,” Massey explained. “That Western kind of pioneer spirit. I think it's a big deal right now.”

;
;
;
;
;

;;
;

;
;
;
;

;After the Marburger opening, Youngblood hosted another huge dinner party at Rancho Pillow, a hotel-venue compound she opened in 2016. Rancho Pillow has a colorful, geographically indiscriminate aesthetic, like an upscale honky-tonk in a Mexican beach town; there's an air-conditioned tepee, a heated saltwater wading pool, and a bathhouse with “Listen” painted on its tin roof.

;

;At dinner, I sat across from the jewelry designer Kendra Scott, a regular “guest shark” on “Shark Tank,” who was at Round Top buying for Yellow Rose, her new ranch-inspired brand. “It's about putting the cowgirl front and center,” she said. She showed me a picture of one of her purchases from the fair: an adult-size mechanical horse from the nineteen-fifties. (In four days of shopping, Scott amassed enough items to fill three trailers.) The look of the moment, she believed, was something rugged but refined. “You know, 'Yellowstone,' and how everybody thinks cowboys are sexy now? And cowgirls!”她说。 “People want those Beth Dutton vibes. You can be tough and sexy. Like, I can run a billion-dollar brand and then go get on my horse along with my sexy cowboy husband—that's a great life.”

;

;A lanky, graying man sitting across from Scott shook his head. His name is Evan Voyles, and he described himself as a “recovering dealer” living in Austin. He was cynical about what Round Top had become. “To call it a theme park would be generous,” he said. “There's interesting stuff in there, but we've undermined it. It used to be old buildings, ;small; buildings, small roads. It wasn't a feeding frenzy. Maybe it's just that I'm getting old, but the stuff isn't looking so good to me anymore.” Voyles said that, in the early nineties, he had briefly owned the world's largest collection of vintage cowboy boots, which he'd acquired by travelling the country, scouring secondhand shops. He'd helped supply the market with old boots, then watched it get overcapitalized. Now Los Angeles boutiques sell mediocre Tony Lama boots from the nineties for hundreds of dollars, the thrift stores are full of fast fashion, and it is nearly impossible to find hidden treasures anymore. Everyone seems to know, or think they know, what things were worth. “It's just like a herd of buffalo builds up over eons, but all it takes is six crazy guys and a market for it to be destroyed in a matter of years,” Voyles said.

;

;I wandered inside to the living room, which was decorated with Youngblood's antique-fair finds—faded rugs, wrought-iron candelabras. At one edge of the room, a well-worn Western saddle hung from a wooden beam. It was covered with circular pieces of mirror, like a DIY cowboy disco ball. Youngblood told me later that it had decorated a dance hall in Kansas in the nineteen-twenties. It was beautiful and strange, and in that moment I desperately wanted to possess it—an old object, full of all the magic I was missing. ♦

;When the best part of a superhero movie is the screenplay, you know you're in trouble. There's enough going on in “The Marvels”—enough situations with dramatic potential, enough twists with imaginative power—to develop several decent movies. Unfortunately, they're snipped and clipped, jammed and rammed, dropped into the movie (and swept out of it) with an informational indifference that doesn't even have the virtue of speed. The heedless rush to splash the story onto the screen leads to an appalling waste of the formidable talents marshalled to depict it.

;

;There are so many undeveloped elements here, but one of the most fundamental is dramatic morality: one mode of tragedy is a conflict of virtues, but there's hardly any villainy in “The Marvels,” and everyone, more or less, has their reasons. The movie, directed by Nia DaCosta (who co-wrote the script with Megan McDonnell and Elissa Karasik), is a follow-up to the 2019 film “;Captain Marvel;.” There, Carol Danvers (Brie Larson), a US Air Force pilot who has gained superpowers (and the moniker of the title), was caught in a war between two space peoples, the Kree and the Skrulls. In the follow-up, Danvers, accused of accidentally extinguishing the sun that made the Kree and Skrulls' planet habitable, is living in a guilt-ridden, self-imposed space exile. She's called back into action by the Avengers' handler Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson) to repair a so-called “jump point,” a kind of space portal. She's joined in this mission by an astronaut named Monica Rambeau (Teyonah Parris), who was a child in the earlier movie. Their work brings them into contact, via a strange intergalactic connection, with a Jersey City teen-ager, Kamala Khan (Iman Vellani), a big fan of Captain Marvel comic books who also has secret superpowers and has a special glowing gauntlet to prove it. The gauntlet is one of a pair, the other of which is in the possession of a Kree warrior named Dar-Benn (Zawe Ashton). She hates Captain Marvel for the destruction of her planet and seeks to maximize her powers by capturing Kamala's gauntlet. Meanwhile, when Monica and Captain Marvel meet at the jump point, they and Kamala all switch places with each other, thus making one another's battles suddenly their own as well.

;

;The results include a handful of showdowns—one in the Khan family house, several in outer space—and some derring-do with spacecraft. There's also some gentle family sitcom involving Kamala's parents (Zenobia Shroff and Mohan Kapur) and her older brother (Saagar Shaikh), who, to his parents' dismay, is still unmarried. There's some blunt and blundering comedy involving Captain Marvel's marriage of convenience to a prince (Park Seo-joon) on a planet whose inhabitants communicate solely by song. There's calculatedly sweet comedy in Kamala's awkward fangirling of Captain Marvel. There's the peculiarity of Captain Marvel's cat, who has a mouthful of yards-long tentacles with which it can swallow creatures many times its own size and spit them back out intact. There's the political wink of the efforts to help the Skrulls, now refugees, find a home. Best of all, there's some mighty faux-scientific mumbo-jumbo involving a rip in the space-time continuum that could, and perhaps should, have been a movie all to itself, with special effects to match.

;
;
;

;Any one of these many elements, obvious and familiar though they may be, could serve as the framework for a popular action fantasy. And the fact that none of the main characters is seriously in the wrong, that all are pursuing worthy ends in disparate ways, also sets things up for complexity. Another reason I had high hopes for this one is that DaCosta's previous film, “;Candyman;,” the fourth film in a long-dormant horror franchise, was written with exploratory fervor and filmed with starkly simple yet dramatically supercharged special effects. But “The Marvels” doesn't give her the leeway to do anything comparable here, and gradually sinks under the weight of convention, formula, and routine. The movie's fight scenes are boilerplate, with no sense of the heroines' vulnerabilities, no sense of what can be escaped from and what can't. Notably, the best effects are the simplest—the sudden appearance of each of the three women in the place of the other, whether teleporting across galaxies or just across the room. (There's nothing in such scenes that couldn't have been done by Georges Méliès ;in the mid-eighteen-nineties;.)

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;What happened to superhero movies? How did a genre rooted in astonishment, weirdness, and wonder become a byword for the normative, the familiar, and the mundane? The paradox of the superhero franchise is that it turns fans of a mythos into ;consumers of a brand;—to the point that, often, behind-the-scenes stories about the brand and its place in the current media scene are far more intricate, impassioned, and engaging than anything happening on the screen. It never ceases to amaze me that the chief Marvel producer, Kevin Feige, with his lifelong love and deep knowledge of comic books, became the Man. Somewhere along the way, executives' suits became more powerful than those of the superheroes they marketed.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;You can see this in the way that the tight formatting of “The Marvels” gives actors as powerful as Larson and Parris and the newcomer Vellani (in her first movie role) little to do. The performances required of them are simply to emblematize emotions in an instant, like humanized emoticons. Larson does so with a steadfast sternness that's one notch short of sheer camp, which I wish she'd unleashed. I've always found something essentially martial in her manner, going back to her performance as a caretaker for troubled teens in the 2013 independent film “;Short Term 12;.” I suspect that she finds a superhero role more artistically gratifying than many actors of her calibre do, and I wish that the movie gave her the space and the time to explore this. (That said, allowing the simple power of a dramatic performance to emerge in a film as confected as “The Marvels” might blow a hole in its own space-time continuum.)

;

;One of the more recent developments in the Marvel franchise has been the embrace of highly distinctive filmmakers, such as DaCosta, Chloé Zhao, and Peyton Reed. This should have guaranteed an ever-expanding universe of cinematic inventiveness—with the budgets (and the hordes of skilled associates listed in the end credits) to back it. Instead, their individual artistry has been largely dominated and overwhelmed by the franchise's systems of production. For all the efforts to widen and diversify the creative teams involved in superhero movies, their key creators are a specific bunch of stuffy and older white men. I'm referring, of course, to the United States Congress, which, in 1976 and again in 1998, extended the terms of copyright so that, under the so-called Mickey Mouse Protection Act, works published before 1978 may be kept under corporate control for ninety-five years. As a result, many of the classic comic-book superheroes remain, even now, decades away from the public domain, decades away from liberation from corporate rights holders. The sway and scope of comic-book stories—the extended universes they envision and the passionate devotion they inspire—arguably make them our contemporary equivalent of ancient religious texts. But, as long as individual studios retain the copyrights, it's as if all representations of Biblical characters and stories were controlled by the Vatican. The result is to keep superhero movies, and much of Hollywood, in an artificial state of immaturity that's indistinguishable from senescence. The movies' extended universes are far narrower than life. ♦

;On Wednesday afternoon, Judge Arthur F. Engoron dismissed Ivanka Trump from the witness stand, and the New York attorney general's office rested its civil fraud case against ;Donald Trump;, his ;two eldest sons;, and the Trump Organization. Ivanka, who was once a Trump Organization executive herself, as well as a White House official and the owner of an apparel business, strode out of the courtroom, and, soon after, cheers and jeers could be heard coming from outside the New York County Courthouse, where a small crowd of onlookers had gathered.

;

;In September, 2022, when the state attorney general, Letitia James, ;first brought the civil charges; against the Trumps, Ivanka was a co-defendant. In June of this year, however, an appeals court dismissed her from the case on the ground that the claims against her were barred by the state's statute of limitations. (She left the Trump Organization in 2017 to serve as an aide in the White House, alongside her husband, ;Jared Kushner;.) After making repeated efforts to avoid testifying, or to delay her appearance, she appeared at the trial as a reluctant witness for the government. In many ways, her nearly five hours of testimony encapsulated the entire trial so far, in substance if not in style.

;

;The substantive outcome of the day was that the attorney general's office used Ivanka's appearance to buttress its argument that the Trump Organization used fraudulent Statements of Financial Condition, which ;greatly exaggerated; Trump's net worth, to help the company get favorable deals from banks and other financial institutions. Louis Solomon, a senior lawyer in the attorney general's office, took Ivanka through a series of documents and e-mails relating to two Trump properties that she worked on extensively: the Doral golf resort in Miami, which the Trump Organization bought and redeveloped, and the government-owned Old Post Office building in Washington, DC, which the Trump Organization leased and converted into a luxury hotel.

;

;Much of the trial, which has been running for the past six weeks, has consisted of similarly laborious exercises involving other witnesses, including Ivanka's father and two brothers. But, if the basic format of Wednesday's proceedings were familiar, the contrast between Ivanka's conduct and that of her family members was glaring. From start to finish, she was polite to a fault. She smiled. She even swapped a lighthearted remark or two with Judge Engoron, who is partial to a bit of banter. All in all, she put on an impressive show, but one that ultimately rested on an acute case of selective amnesia.

;

;Time after time, Solomon asked Ivanka whether she recalled certain communications or recognized certain exhibits. And, time after time, Ivanka said that she didn't. Many of these communications involved Deutsche Bank, which gave the Trump Organization low-cost loans to finance the redevelopment of Doral and the conversion of the Old Post Office building. Solomon produced a November, 2011, document in which the securities division of Deutsche Bank, which operated separately from the private-wealth division, offered to supply a loan for Doral at an interest rate equal to the London Interbank Offered Rate (;LIBOR;) plus eight per cent. Ivanka said she didn't recall having seen these terms. Solomon then produced a December, 2011, e-mail from Rosemary Vrablic, a senior executive in the private-wealth department at Deutsche, which contained an offer to provide two loans for the Doral project at interest rates equal to ;LIBOR; plus two per cent and 2.5 per cent. It doesn't take a finance wiz to figure out that ;LIBOR; plus two per cent is a much better interest rate than ;LIBOR; plus eight per cent.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Ivanka said she recalled that she “received high-level terms” from Vrablic, but she said she didn't remember this particular proposal. Solomon then produced an e-mail that Ivanka sent to other Trump executives shortly after Vrablic e-mailed her, in which she forwarded the loan terms that the banker had offered. “It doesn't get better than this. Let's discuss ASAP,” the e-mail said. After reading it out, Solomon asked the witness: “Does this refresh your memory on whether you thought this was a good proposal for the Trump Organization?” Ivanka replied: “I think what we ended up doing was slightly different. But, yes, I thought generally the deal was positive.”

;
;
;

;A key difference between the two loan offers from Deutsche Bank was that the one from the private-wealth department required a personal guarantee from Trump and the one from the securities division didn't. Solomon brought up an e-mail that Ivanka received from Jason Greenblatt, a lawyer at the Trump Organization, in which Greenblatt pointed out that the offer from Vrablic required Trump to personally guarantee the loans and maintain a minimum net worth of three billion dollars, which “would seem to me to be a problem?” as Greenblatt put it. Ivanka replied: “That we have known from day one. We wanted to get a great rate and the only way to get proceeds/term and principle where we want them is to guarantee the deal.” Solomon asked the witness if she recalled writing this email. No, she replied.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The point of all this was to try and demonstrate that Trump received favorable loan terms based, at least in part, on the net worth he claimed in his Statements of Financial Condition. Ivanka said she had nothing to do with the preparation of these statements and knew little about them. But Solomon also produced a copy of the final loan agreement with Deutsche Bank from 2012. It included a minimum net-worth requirement of $2.5 billion and noted that Trump had supplied the bank with a copy of his financial statements.

;
;
;

;Occasionally, Ivanka was able to conjure up some more detailed memories. She remembered that the original letter informing her that the Trumps could purchase Doral had appeared as she was just about to have a baby. She also recalled, at some length, a 2011 meeting in Washington, DC, with the federal General Services Administration, at which she, her father, and other Trump executives presented their vision for redeveloping the Old Post Office building. But she insisted that she didn't remember discussing anything about Trump's financial statements with the GSA “When I ask a question, she doesn't remember,” a frustrated Solomon remarked to Judge Engoron. “The witness does have a recollection, Your Honor!”

;

;Even the attorney general seemed impressed by the smoothness of Ivanka's performance on the witness stand. “Ivanka Trump was cordial, she was disciplined, she was controlled, and she was very courteous,” James told reporters outside the courthouse. However, the attorney general went on, the documentary evidence had clearly shown that the witness was “involved in negotiating and securing loans, favorable loans, for the benefit of the Trump Organization, for Mr. Trump and her brothers and for herself. 。 。 。 The documents do not lie. The numbers do not lie.”

;

;In a case built heavily on documents, that is the challenge facing Trump's defense team. Starting on Monday, they will attempt to convince the court that the documentary evidence, although voluminous, doesn't prove that Trump and the Trump Organization acted with fraudulent intent or that the bogus valuations contained in the Statements of Financial Condition imposed any financial harm on the banks and other financial companies that received them.

;

;Before Ivanka left the witness stand, Jesus Suarez, a member of the Trump defense team, made a start on this endeavor by cross-examining her about the Trump Organization's relationship with Deutsche Bank. Suarez produced an e-mail in which Vrablic asked Ivanka if she would feature in one of its promotional videos. Ivanka said she couldn't remember whether she did the video, but added that Deutsche was constantly saying “how much they appreciated our relationship.” Suarez also brought up a meeting between Donald Trump and Deutsche's then co-CEO Anshu Jain at Trump Tower, in March, 2013. Ivanka seemed to have a clear recollection of this occasion. She claimed that Jain encouraged the Trumps to do more business with the bank. When Suarez asked her how her father reacted to the meeting, she said, “He was very positive. It was a very nice meeting.” ♦

;Two and a half months ago, the top election official in Minnesota, Steve Simon, received a letter from Free Speech for People (FSFP), a small nonpartisan organization that advocates for democratic principles. The letter asked Simon, as secretary of state, to do something that has never been done before: prevent a former President, ;Donald Trump;, from appearing on the state's 2024 election ballots. “Under the Fourteenth Amendment to the US Constitution, Mr. Trump is constitutionally ineligible to appear on any future ballot for federal office based on his engagement in insurrection against the United States,” it said. “Allowing a known insurrectionist to appear on the ballot is inconsistent with your prior commitments and your oath of office to support the US Constitution.”

;

;Simon, a Democrat, wasn't so sure. Section 3 of the Fourteenth Amendment says that anyone who has taken an oath to uphold the Constitution, and then participates in an insurrection—or gives aid or comfort to those who have—is disqualified from holding any office, civil or military. But Simon told me that he does not take a position on the eligibility of individual candidates. He wanted a judge to decide whether the ballots could feature Trump's name. “Our job is to serve the voters, and for courts to do the fact-finding and make conclusions of law,” he told me. “There is an expectation here that the person who holds this office will leave their politics at the door . 。 。 and not do anything that creates the appearance of putting their thumb on the scale for any candidate, any political party, or any ballot question.”

;

;On the day that Simon received the letter, Paul Anderson, a retired justice of the Minnesota Supreme Court, happened to be at the state capitol, preparing to give a tour of the building to some guests. Anderson had sat on the court for nineteen years until he reached the mandatory retirement age of seventy. (He is now eighty.) A moderate Republican for most of his life, he broke with the Party after it named Trump as its Presidential candidate in 2016. He was in the rotunda when Charles Nauen, a prominent lawyer whose clients include the Minnesota affiliate of the Democratic Party, came over for a chat.

;

;Nauen told Anderson about a lawsuit that he and FSFP were bringing against Secretary of State Simon, which could compel Simon to block Trump from the state's primary ballot. The case would be heard by Anderson's former colleagues on the Minnesota Supreme Court. Then, Nauen made an unorthodox request: Would Anderson consider becoming a petitioner in the case?

;

;“I was evasive, and dodged Charlie's direct question,” Anderson told me. “Charlie seemed resigned to the fact that I would not consent to be part of the lawsuit.” In the days that followed, however, they talked further. Anderson weighed Nauen's request carefully. If he joined the lawsuit, a longtime Republican would be challenging a Democrat in hope of constraining Donald Trump. “What we're dealing with here is so much beyond partisan labels,” he told me. In the end, when FSFP and Nauen filed the lawsuit against Simon, on September 12th, Anderson was one of eight high-profile Minnesotans on the petition.

;

;Minnesota is one of three states in which nonprofits have recruited high-profile voters, including current and former Republicans, to file Section 3 lawsuits. A similar case in Michigan, brought by FSFP together with local attorneys, aims to compel Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson to leave Trump's name off the ballot. Meanwhile, in Colorado, Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (;CREW;), a nonpartisan watchdog organization, is suing Trump and Jena Griswold, the Colorado secretary of state. There is some irony that the suit names them both as co-defendants: Griswold deems Trump a danger to the country, blames him for ;the storming of the US Capitol on January 6th;, and considers that day an insurrection.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;In the coming year, these cases could inflame political divisions and cast a shadow of uncertainty over the 2024 election. The Trump supporters behind the January 6th attacks claimed that an election was stolen from them; now that their violence, and Trump's role in it, has led to lawsuits, more claims of a stolen or rigged election could follow. Even Anderson, as a petitioner in Minnesota, worries about what would happen if Trump were actually disqualified from elections. “I am very concerned that it could lead to people being violent,” he told me. “There are people who will want to vote for him, and think it's their right to vote for him—and that's a scary proposition.”

;

;On November 2nd, FSFP made its case before the Minnesota Supreme Court. During the hearing, the justices seemed most interested in figuring out whether a state court has a role to play in constitutional questions about Section 3. Minutes into a presentation by Ron Fein, an FSFP lawyer, the chief justice, Natalie Hudson, asked him a question: Even if the court has the authority to keep Trump's name off the ballot, should it? “That's the question that concerns me the most,” Hudson said.

;

;In response, Fein said that Trump could always “seek review in the US Supreme Court, which could provide a final answer to the question.” His knowledge of case law seemed encyclopedic; he pointed to a Minnesota statute that, he said, gave the justices no choice but to rule here.

;
;
;

;On Wednesday evening, they did. The court said that Minnesota law does not prohibit a major political party from placing an ineligible candidate on its primary ballot. In its view, Trump can appear on the ballot regardless of whether Section 3 disqualifies him from the Presidency. Even so, the case may not end there. As Fein pointed out, an appeal could end up in the Supreme Court. Meanwhile, the court gave the petitioners the option of bringing the same claims during the general election. “The court's opinion was not a surprise,” Anderson told me in an e-mail on Thursday. “The court temporized and put off the main issue for another day.”

;
;
;

;;CREW;'s case against Griswold and Trump, in Colorado, began on October 30th. The ;CREW; brief laid out Trump's complicity in the January 6th attacks in excruciating detail, arguing that, if Griswold allows Trump to run in the primary, it will be “an impropriety.” Their witnesses included two police officers who had fought off rioters at the Capitol and a Democratic member of Congress who described hiding from the attackers. In response, Trump's lawyers argued that the former President did not incite the January 6th attack and that it was not an insurrection. They tried and failed to get the judge to separate the former President's case from Griswold's.

;

;Griswold and her fellow election officers are in a complicated position. “We're hoping that the court will clarify whether Section 3 of the Fourteenth Amendment applies to ballot access,” she told me. As the Minnesota ruling suggests, Trump may be found eligible to appear on the ballot regardless of his eligibility to be sworn in as President. But Griswold added, “We've never had a President incite an insurrection and attack our democracy like Trump has.” A ruling in the Colorado case is expected by Thanksgiving.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;No matter the outcome, the stakes will be high. After ;CREW; filed its case, the chair of the Colorado Republican Party called the lawsuit ;treasonous; and said, “We won't take it lying down.” Griswold's office received more than sixty death threats and nine hundred abusive calls. The reaction was so intense that the judge overseeing the case, in Colorado's Second Judicial District Court, issued a protective order to keep the parties safe. (The Colorado petitioners are not talking to the press.) Meanwhile, in Michigan, the office of Secretary of State Benson, who encountered armed protesters after the 2020 election, was inundated with “very vitriolic messages on both sides,” she told me. “I very clearly said, In Michigan, the former President is going to be on the ballot unless the court rules otherwise. That's turned the volume down a bit on some of the threats.”

;

;Congress passed three ;Reconstruction amendments; in the years after the Civil War. The Thirteenth Amendment abolished slavery, while the Fifteenth Amendment established voting rights for all men (women had to wait another fifty years). The Fourteenth Amendment is best known for granting citizenship to “all persons born or naturalized in the United States” and for securing due process and equal protection of the laws “to any person within its jurisdiction.” But lawmakers of the time were also grappling with a thorny dilemma: what to do about former secessionists who wanted to hold political office in the newly mended nation.

;

;After the ratification of the Fourteenth Amendment, in 1868, Section 3 was used to remove former Confederates from Congress, and to keep others out of office. But, in 1872, Congress granted amnesty to those who aided and abetted the Confederacy. As a result, Section 3 was mostly forgotten—until the storming of the Capitol on January 6, 2021. Armed Trump supporters, encouraged by the outgoing President, breached the halls of Congress in order to disrupt the certification of the election. Trump watched from the White House and, for hours, did nothing to stop them. In the days afterward, many observers, including high-ranking Republicans, were calling it an insurrection. Section 3 suddenly seemed timely and prescient.

;

;The petitioners in Minnesota, Michigan, and Colorado are not the first to note that Section 3 might disqualify Trump from becoming President again. “In fact, the articles of impeachment against Trump, in 2021, mentioned Section 3,” Fein, who is also litigating the Michigan case, said. “But we were the first to realize that Section 3 can be enforced using existing state law.” What he means is that each state has its own rules about which candidates can appear on ballots; if Trump really is ineligible for the Presidency, under Section 3, some states could stop him from being listed at all.

;

;In 2022, in one of several precedents for the current lawsuits, Fein and his colleagues ;challenged; ;Marjorie Taylor Greene;'s eligibility to run for reëlection under Section 3, in a filing addressed to Georgia's secretary of state, Brad Raffensperger. Greene, a Trump acolyte, had encouraged supporters to protest the certification of Biden's victory, calling it their “1776 moment.” ;Fein lost; the case. “The evidence does not show Rep. Greene engaged in months of planning and plotting to bring about the Invasion and defeat the orderly transfer of power provided for in our Constitution,” the judge wrote.

;

;Fein's team also sought to prevent Representative ;Madison Cawthorn;, of North Carolina, from running for reëlection, arguing that he had helped to incite the insurrection through his public remarks. After the North Carolina State Board of Elections determined that it had the authority to decide whether Cawthorn was disqualified under Section 3, the chief judge of the US District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina ;ruled; that the amnesty of 1872 essentially repealed Section 3. While the appeal was pending, Cawthorn lost his primary, and the question of whether he was qualified for office lost relevance. But ;CREW; lawyers had better luck in New Mexico. In September, 2022, they successfully used Section 3 ;to remove; a sitting county commissioner who had participated in the attack on the Capitol.

;
;
;

;Any court that takes up the question of Trump's eligibility under Section 3 will have to start by deciding whether the section remains in force today, or whether it is a historical artifact that was meant to apply solely to Civil War rebels. If it is still in effect, the court will then be tasked with untying various semantic knots. Does Section 3 apply to the Presidency? What constitutes an insurrection? What exactly are “aid” and “comfort”? Notably, Section 3 does not mention elections, and it was written before primaries existed; the Minnesota Supreme Court pointed out that, in the state, a primary is an internal party matter, outside the jurisdiction of the secretary of state. In a sense, what's ultimately on trial is the meaning of Section 3 itself.

;

;Fein and his colleagues at FSFP launched their effort to disqualify Trump in June, 2021, by sending preliminary letters to every chief election officer in the country. The letters argued that, if Trump tried to seek the Presidency again, he would be ineligible under Section 3—and that secretaries of state had the authority and the obligation to keep him off the ballot. As soon as Trump declared his intention to run again, in November, 2022, FSFP announced that it would be challenging him in multiple states.

;

;An effort to disqualify a popular politician, using a constitutional clause that had essentially laid dormant for a century and a half, may seem quixotic or even misguided. This summer, however, a pre-publication draft of a ;law-review article; made the case that Section 3 disqualifies Trump from the Presidency. Law reviews rarely make news, but this one did—not only because of its careful reasoning but because its two authors, William Baude and Michael Stokes Paulsen, are well-known conservative jurists. Both are members of the Federalist Society, which interprets the Constitution through an originalist lens; their jurisprudence derives from what they see as the intent of the Framers, based on both a semantic and historical analysis of the text.

;

;There are two main conclusions that Baude and Paulsen reach. First, January 6th was an insurrection—shorter in duration than the Civil War, obviously, but with no less of an intent to subvert the constitutional order. Second, because Donald Trump took an oath to preserve and protect the Constitution when he was sworn into office in 2017, and because Section 3 explicitly disqualifies any insurrectionist who has taken such an oath, it applies to Trump. They write that, whatever one calls January 6th, “such conduct is covered by Section Three, and is disqualifying.” The fact that a law has not been dusted off in decades, they note, does not render it moot: “The First Amendment is old too, as is the entire original Constitution. But both remain in force.”

;Fein told me that the article, which is slated to run in the ;University of Pennsylvania Law Review; next year, “injected a great deal of new energy into the national conversation about these issues, and helped to elevate them—and, perhaps, give some gravitas that this is not a partisan issue.” There was considerable overlap between Baude and Paulsen's arguments, Fein said, and the ones that his team was already preparing to make in court. “It agrees with what we have been researching and saying for years now,” he said.

;

;Perhaps the most powerful objection to using Section 3 to keep Trump off the ballot is that it is undemocratic to prevent the American people from voting for the candidate of their choice. This is the position of another prominent conservative jurist, Michael W. McConnell. “We are talking about empowering partisan politicians such as state secretaries of state to disqualify their political opponents from the ballot, depriving voters of the ability to elect candidates of their choice,” McConnell ;has said;. “If abused, this is profoundly anti-democratic.” McConnell cites a landmark 1964 civil-rights decision, in Reynolds v. Sims, which declared: “The right to vote freely for the candidate of one's choice is of the essence of a democratic society, and any restrictions on that right strike at the heart of representative government.”

;

;Baude and Paulsen counter that this is a political argument, not a legal one—and the Constitution, in their view, is apolitical. There are already restrictions on the people Americans can vote for: a Presidential candidate must be a natural-born American over the age of thirty-five, and the Twenty-second Amendment prohibits a two-term President from running again, even if voters are willing to elect them. There is also precedent for enforcing these restrictions on the state level. Before ;Neil Gorsuch; became a Supreme Court Justice, he sat on the US Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. In 2012, he ruled that Scott Gessler, the Republican secretary of state of Colorado at the time, had the right to “exclude from the ballot candidates who are constitutionally prohibited from assuming office.” (In a curious twist, Gessler is now one of Trump's lawyers in the Colorado litigation.)

;

;There are many possible outcomes here. Whether judges rule in favor of Trump or against him, they may trigger an appeal. In Colorado and Michigan, lower-court judges could also decide that the cases are not “ripe”—that is, not ready for adjudication because the issue that they raise is not imminent. Trump hasn't run or won yet, so the question of his disqualification is arguably in the future. (Minnesota's laws are a bit different; all eligibility challenges to federal candidates go straight to the state's highest court.)

;

;A Supreme Court decision could potentially adjudicate these cases in various ways. It could agree with Trump's lawyers that January 6th was not an insurrection or, if it was, that Trump was not materially involved. Or it could accept the argument of a lawyer for Trump in Minnesota, Nicholas Nelson—that courts shouldn't decide “who can or can't be President.” It could also subscribe to Baude and Paulsen's originalist reading of Section 3, and disqualify the former President.

;If the Supreme Court does take on this challenge, they are most likely to take Michael W. McConnell's advice and rule as narrowly as possible, to prevent Section 3 from being abused in the future. ;Richard Hasen;, an elections-law expert who directs the Safeguarding Democracy Project at UCLA, told me that he is less concerned with how the Court rules than that they do so very quickly. “Sometimes it's more important for the law to be certain than to be right,” he said. “It will be a disaster if Trump wins the election, and Democrats control Congress, and they don't let him assume the Presidency because they say he's not qualified. And, for Republican voters, they shouldn't be voting for a candidate who's not qualified. So this needs resolution.”

;For Anderson, the retired Minnesota Supreme Court justice, the real question is: “should Trump, under our system of rule, be held accountable for his actions?” That's what convinced him, finally, to add his name to the lawsuit. “The American system of democracy is just so deeply rooted in me that, when somebody makes an assault on it, I'm offended,” he told me. “Benjamin Franklin said, 'It's a republic if you can keep it.' And so I'm willing to stand up and try to keep it.” ♦
